questions.question_text: A law office has been leasing dark fiber from a local telecommunications company to connect a remote office to company headquarters. The telecommunications company has decided to discontinue its dark fiber product and is offering an MPLS connection, which the law office feels is too expensive. Which of the following is the BEST solution for the law office?

discussion.content: Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data from one node to the next based on short path labels rather than long network addresses, thus avoiding complex lookups in a routing table and speeding traffic flows. The labels identify virtual links (paths) between distant nodes rather than endpoints. MPLS can encapsulate packets of various network protocols, hence the "multiprotocol" reference on its name. MPLS supports a range of access technologies, including T1/E1, ATM, Frame Relay, and DSL.

A site-to-site virtual private network (VPN) is a connection between two or more networks, such as a corporate network and a branch office network. Many organizations use site-to-site VPNs to leverage an internet connection for private traffic as an alternative to using private MPLS circuits.

Kerberos is an enterprise authentication protocol that uses the concept of tickets and three-way authentication to enable users and computers to identify themselves and secure access to resources. Composer supports Kerberos as a Single Sign On (SSO) mechanism
Key phrase is "remote office to headquarters" - therefore Site-to-Site VPN

questions.question_text: An analyst is part of a team that is investigating a potential breach of sensitive data at a large financial services organization. The organization suspects a breach occurred when proprietary data was disclosed to the public. The team finds servers were accessed using shared credentials that have been in place for some time. In addition, the team discovers undocumented firewall rules, which provided unauthorized external access to a server. Suspecting the activities of a malicious insider threat, which of the following was MOST likely to have been utilized to exfiltrate the proprietary data?

discussion.content: Key word "have been in place for some time"

Most definitely not A-Keylogger
This scenario doesn't suggest the activity of a Botnet either so not B
No files have been encrypted so not C or E 
F is only tricky but not F 
Provided answer is correct. D - Backdoor

comments.content: F is not tricky, DLP would have alerted to and possibly stopped this from happening.
D is definitely the answer as the info given in the question is asking what was used to exfiltrate data.

discussion.content: Keyword: asking what was used to EXFILTRATE data

questions.question_text:
An organization is providing employees on the shop floor with computers that will log their time based on when they sign on and off the network.
Which of the following account types should the employees receive?

discussion.content:
User account : Most accounts are for regular users. Admin create these accounts and then assign appropriate privileges based on the user's job responsibilities. 
Prvilieged account: has additional rights and privileges beyond a regular user has.
Guest accounts : windows operating system includes guess accounts. 
Service account: some application and services need to run under the context of a account and service account fill this need.

comments.content: WOW padhini !! Really? got 100$ says you failed 1st attempt
If it's a shared account, how will the company differentiate between different users...Aka, who logged on and off and when. !!

discussion.content: It should be a shared account.
it should be D I guess. The firewall is blocking certain key words and that is why the user can not access

comments.content: That would probably violate company security policies.
I cant see from the question if the block is from the Host based firewall or the proxy
You can make changes to the host-based firewall, but it is being blocked by the proxy, so it can't be D
To solve a specific problem of accessing job sites, you're giving much more access than required. This violates least privilege so its not right.

discussion.content: Make sense to move the user to a less restricted group!!! B is the right choice!

choices.D: Create an exception for the job search sites in the host-based firewall on the employee's computer
choices.C: Remove the proxy settings from the employee's web browser
choices.A: Renew the DNS settings and IP address on the employee's computer
choices.B: Add the employee to a less restrictive group on the content filter

comments.content: Your comment is actually inaccurate. A minimum password age does not mean the password wont expire, it actually means that you can change the password instantly...no time has to pass. As this is a service account that is used for critical updates, this minimum password age setting is required. On the other hand, the maximum password age dictates how long you can keep a password before changing it. Considering the type of account, the selected answer is correct.
Nope...then a lazy admin just changes it 4 times and wamo it is what it was and he doesn't have to update his records.
correct, 0 min age means password can never expire.
I think u right. Bc if no minimum age is set it means they can change passwords more than 10 times in a day which I think is not good

discussion.content: Answer should be c. Never have min at zero

Provided answer is correct.

A - keyword "Disable", you need lockout policy 
C - minimum password age is always 0/zero
D - definitely not the answer

Answer is A
A service account is a user account that is created to run a particular service or software. To prevent an outage of the service if the password expires, you can configure the user account password not to expire. This will also mean that the administrator will need to remember to change the password at regular intervals to ensure good security. In line with the principle of least privilege, a service account should be given the minimum amount of rights it needs to operate.

comments.content: Messer isn't COMTIA. Think about it, what is the value of changing passwords if the user can change back to the same password every single time? Min password age needs to exist.

discussion.content:
Professor Messer Notes: Password expiration and recovery
• All passwords should expire
• Change every 30 days, 60 days, 90 days
• Critical systems might change more frequently
• Every 15 days or every week
• The recovery process should not be trivial!
• Some organizations have a very formal process

Yes answer is A because the service account is running critical network services. If you lock out of the service account then it could cause the service to not work. Usually these are automated services and locking out of account you can't interact with those services and they may stop working.

Answer is A service accounts should not have lockout if the service is needed key word is "critical".


https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/services-hub/health/remediation-steps-ad/set-the-account-lockout-threshold-to-the-recommended-value#:~:text=The%20account%20lockout%20threshold%20should,still%20ensures%20that%20a%20brute

comments.content: To lock out a service account for whole day could cause real problems another question Comptia can just randomly decide. :/

choices.C: Set the minimum password age to seven days
choices.B: Set the maximum password age to 15 days
